The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (thresholded whole-brain maps at p<0.001 with cluster extent and reported activated regions and coordinates) as well as SVC results. The sample is within the 18–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported. The study is empirical fMRI (task-based) and not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets the review inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of affective theory-of-mind (social cognition) in healthy adults (N=21 after QC, mean age 23.7), satisfying the population criterion. The study used task-based fMRI during a social/affective ToM cartoon task and reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (second-level one-sample t-tests) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster results (Tables 1-4), and figures showing activation maps. Whole-brain results for the healthy/control group are clearly described; coordinate tables and cluster statistics are provided. Although ROI and PPI analyses are also reported, whole-brain task activation maps and coordinates are present. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI experiment investigating processing of empathic vs. unempathic social responses (social cognition / perception and understanding of others). The sample comprises 20 healthy adult participants (mean age 26), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and voxelwise results (tables with MNI coordinates, FWE-corrected clusters, and whole-brain contrasts such as EE>EN, CE>baseline, negative>positive feedback). Results are not limited to ROI, resting-state, or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly reported. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of perception of facial expressions (a social communication / perception-of-others task) in healthy adult participants (n=24, mean age 25.2). The paper reports group-level fMRI analyses (mixed-effects FLAME), parameter estimate maps registered to MNI space, and a group-level localiser contrast (faces > scrambled faces) used to define face-selective regions, i.e., whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts from healthy participants. Results include group-level statistical analyses and whole-brain-based anatomical region comparisons. Thus the study meets the review’s requirements for a task-based social fMRI study in healthy adults and reports group-level whole-brain results.

This is an fMRI study (NeuroImage, 2016) using a social-evaluative task (watching approving/disapproving videos). The sample comprises 37 healthy adult participants (mean age 24.8). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (negative>neutral, positive>neutral), a conjunction analysis, whole-brain FWE-corrected results, and coordinate tables/figures (Tables 2–4, Figs. 3–5). Results are clearly presented for the healthy/control group. Therefore it satisfies I3, I4, I5 and I6 and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition: participants (N=30 healthy, right-handed White adults, age 18–29) completed an fMRI face-perception task and later trustworthiness ratings. The task probes perception/understanding of others (race perception/trustworthiness), meeting the social-related task requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (e.g., Black > White contrasts; covariate analyses) and provides tables of peak coordinates (Tables 2 and 3) and statistical maps, satisfying whole-brain reporting. Results for the healthy adult sample are reported directly. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (I3, I4, I5, I6) and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (person perception and person knowledge) using a task manipulating bodies vs names and trait vs neutral statements, addressing social cognition. Participants are healthy adults (N=21, mean age 24.6), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked univariate contrasts (e.g., Bodies>Names, Traits>Neutral, interaction [(BodiesTraits>BodiesNeutral)>(NamesTraits>NamesNeutral)]) with coordinates, thresholds, and overlaps with localisers; these satisfy the requirement for whole-brain voxelwise results. Whole-brain results are described in the text and figures/tables. Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, they are not the sole analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of theory-of-mind/social cognition in healthy adults (N=24, mean age 25.7) that directly examines social processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects task contrasts (e.g., social>non-social in Background; unexpected>expected in Outcome) with tables of peak MNI coordinates and cluster statistics, and ROI/MVPA analyses. Healthy adult results are reported explicitly and not limited to a clinical subgroup. Thus the study meets inclusion criteria: uses fMRI for social-related tasks (I3); includes healthy adult participants within 18–65 (I4); reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise maps/contrasts (I5); and provides whole-brain results in tables/figures (I6). No exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=23, ages 21–43) that used a task requiring social judgments of faces (social cognition). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (Social Judgment > Perceptual Judgment) with FWE-corrected cluster results presented in tables and figures, and extracts whole-cluster eigenvariates for regression analyses. All required elements for inclusion are present: task-based fMRI of a social-related construct, a healthy adult sample within 18–65, and clearly reported whole-brain group results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, non-empirical, or out-of-range samples) are met. Therefore the study meets the review’s inclusion criteria and is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=25, mean age 24) that explicitly probes social-related processing: participants evaluated LEGO models for meaning (social/semantic properties) versus physical properties and contrasts include own vs other and collective vs individual. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and peak coordinates (Table 1) with appropriate correction (FDR/FWE) for several contrasts (e.g., meaning > physical, own > other), satisfying whole-brain reporting. Methods, participants, and contrasts are clearly described for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an fMRI study using the Cyberball ball-toss social interaction task (a social-related paradigm assessing social reward/interaction). Participants were healthy adults (final N=31, mean age ~21, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., ball-toss [high-frequency – normal-frequency] > button-press [high-frequency – normal-frequency]) with peak coordinates and cluster-level FWE-corrected statistics, clearly from the healthy/control group. Results are presented as whole-brain maps/coordinates in text/tables. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion requirements for the review.

This study reports task-state fMRI focused on episodic memory retrieval and functional connectivity of self-referential, executive and salience sub-networks in aMCI and control participants. However, it does not present a group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group; analyses are ROI- and seed-based functional connectivity (correlation/Fisher z) and network-level conjunctions rather than unmasked whole-brain task activation contrasts. Therefore it meets exclusion criterion E3 (seed-based/connectivity-only results without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map). Although the paper discusses self-referential processing (a social-related construct), the primary analyses are connectivity-based, so it fails the whole-brain task-activation requirement (I5) and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study that directly investigates socially-induced emotion regulation (Social-Reg) — a clearly social-related task involving affiliation/attachment and social cognition. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (female, ages 22–32) and group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts are reported (e.g., Social-Reg > Social-Look) with tables of coordinates and cluster-level statistics (Tables 1–3 and figures). Resting-state and Self-Reg controls are also present but do not preclude the reporting of unmasked whole-brain task activations for the healthy group. Thus the paper meets all required inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study using a social interaction task (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) probing retaliatory aggression, which fits the review’s social-related processing scope. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=15, mean age 22.3), meeting the age and healthy-sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses including voxelwise statistical maps, cluster thresholds, and Talairach coordinates (reported in tables and figures), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented (within-group contrasts and parametric modulation analyses). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state-only, between-group-only contrasts, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical work) apply. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition using an interactive Prisoner’s Dilemma task that elicits mentalizing (a social-related construct). The sample includes healthy adults (n=195 for behavioral/structural analyses; n=163 for fMRI), ages 19–38, meeting the adult healthy participant criterion. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (ment > cont) analyzed with SPM8 and reports cluster- and FWE-corrected results, tables of significant clusters/coordinates, and whole-brain activation maps for the healthy sample. Thus it provides the required healthy-group whole-brain task activation maps and coordinate tables. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical, out-of-range participants, or only between-group contrasts without healthy-group task maps) are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social processes (charitable giving, empathy, perspective taking) in healthy adult participants (N=33, ages 20–34). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (searchlight MVPA and GLM contrasts) with corrected statistical thresholds (p<0.05 FWE) and tables/figures of results. The methods and results clearly present healthy-group task-evoked whole-brain effects. Thus it meets the review’s criteria for inclusion.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in a large sample of healthy adults (N=178, mean age 40.9, within 18–65). The task (EmpaToM) manipulates empathy and Theory of Mind and constitutes a social-related task. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (emotional vs neutral videos; ToM vs non-ToM questions/videos) and provides activation tables/coordinates and figures clearly derived from the healthy/control group. Whole-brain results are explicitly described in text, tables, and figures. Though additional connectivity/DCM analyses are reported, whole-brain task activation is present and clearly reported for the healthy sample, meeting the inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (final N=18, ages 21–38) examining social cognition (cooperation vs. competition). The task is social and theory-of-mind related, and the paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task activation results (univariate whole-brain contrasts with cluster tables and coordinates) as well as ROI and MVPA analyses. Thus it satisfies the review's requirements for fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults with reported whole-brain results.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults: participants (n=18, mean age 23.7) performed a social inference task (inferring targets' emotions) during fMRI, meeting the review’s social-related task requirement. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise GLM analyses (conjunctions, contrasts) with tables of coordinates and figures describing results for the healthy sample. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of impression updating—a social-cognitive task (perception/understanding of others). Participants were healthy adults (N=21, ages 18–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., L2>F3; interaction and targeted whole-brain contrasts) with tables of peak coordinates and figures, corrected for multiple comparisons. Whole-brain results are clearly described for the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review (I3, I4, I5, I6) and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition) in healthy adults (n=19, ages 20–53). The REMICS task explicitly manipulates social vs. physical scenarios and contextual adjustments, and the paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., SocAdj > PhyConf; Soc > Phy; Adj > Conf) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster statistics, and figures showing whole-brain activations. Results for the healthy/control group are reported separately. The study therefore meets the review objective and satisfies the whole-brain reporting requirement (coordinates/tables acceptable). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (mean age ~31) that uses the Ultimatum Game, a social economic exchange task probing social decision-making and cooperation. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (random-effects ANOVA, conjunction analyses, whole-brain parametric regressions) with coordinates and corrected statistics, clearly from the healthy participant groups. Methods and results provide whole-brain statistical maps and coordinate tables. Thus it meets the meta-analysis objective and inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

The study uses fMRI during social tasks in healthy adults (theory-of-mind and social attribution-of-attention) and meets I3 and I4. However, it does not report a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise activation map for the healthy group. Task-related analyses were performed using localized ICA within a TPJ ROI (ROI-limited task decomposition) and task relevance was assessed via IC time-course regressions; whole-brain results are limited to seed-to-voxel functional connectivity maps (connectivity, not task-evoked activation). Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain task activation reporting and meets exclusion criteria E2 and E3.

The study is an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=40, mean age 27.8) using a social task (modified Cyberball) that probes social exclusion and evaluative stress. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Exclusion > Inclusion; PG EX > FG EX) with voxel-level FWE correction and tables/figures of peak coordinates and clusters. Therefore it satisfies the review inclusion criteria for task (I3), sample (I4), whole-brain group-level reporting (I5), and acceptable reporting format (I6). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample) are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of healthy adults (N=34, mean age 22.2) who engaged in naturalistic movie viewing that evokes social cognition (scenes of social interaction). The task assesses social-related processing (perception/understanding of others) during functional MRI. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (whole-brain reverse-correlation maps, Figure 3, χ2 tests and cluster maps) in addition to ROI analyses, and these whole-brain results are clearly described for the healthy/control group. Thus the study meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related task (I3), healthy adult sample (I4), and reporting of whole-brain task-evoked results (I5/I6). No exclusion criteria appear to apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=20; ages 23–33) using a social perception task (viewing actors grasping objects with neutral/joyful/angry expressions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., angry session > joyful session; main effect of grasping) with FWE-corrected results and tables/coordinates, fulfilling whole-brain reporting requirements. While it also includes PPI and DCM connectivity analyses and ROI-focused hypotheses, whole-brain voxelwise results for the healthy sample are clearly reported. Therefore all inclusion criteria for the review are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (self-reference vs other-reference) in a sample of 110 healthy adults aged 19–31. The paper presents group-level whole-brain GLM contrasts (e.g., self>other, other>self, social>baseline) with FWE-corrected thresholds and reports whole-brain results in text, figures and tables. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6. No exclusion criteria (E2–E6) are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing using economic games (PD, UG/WG) with explicit sociality manipulations (human/acquaintance vs computer/random individual), constituting social-related tasks. Samples are healthy adult participants (Pilot N=10, Main N=15; ages college-aged/adults) meeting the 18–65 criterion. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task activation analyses using standard pipelines (FSL for Pilot, SPM12 for Main), with thresholding (Z>2.3, p<0.05 cluster; P<0.05 FWE) and coordinates/activation tables and figures, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain evidence. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses (although PPI is also reported), and healthy-group task activations are clearly described. Therefore all specified inclusion criteria are met.

This is a task-based fMRI study of attachment-related social stimuli (Adult Attachment Projective Picture System) in healthy adults (N=25, ages 19–26). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (attachment vs neutral) with MNI coordinates and cluster-level corrected statistics, clearly described for the healthy/control group. Behavioral validation of stimuli and detailed methods of fMRI acquisition and preprocessing are provided. Thus all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=24; age 19–31) using an explicit social task (cooperation vs competition) that probes perception/understanding of self and others. The paper reports task-evoked BOLD analyses, identifies whole-brain regions (pgACC and area 9) tracking self- and other-performance, and describes group-level GLM and whole-brain results and contrasts. Whole-brain results are described in the main text (with ROI follow-ups), satisfying the requirement for voxelwise group-level task activation maps. Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (mean age ~21) using a social task (one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma) that probes social cooperation. The paper reports both ROI and whole-brain (voxelwise) group-level task-evoked contrasts with coordinates and cluster-level statistics (FWE-corrected), clearly reported for the healthy/control group. Thus it meets criteria for social-related fMRI (I3), healthy adult sample (I4), whole-brain group-level results (I5), and acceptable reporting format (I6). No exclusion criteria are triggered.

This peer-reviewed study uses task-based fMRI to investigate social cognition (valence judgments of naturalistic social interactions) in a sample of healthy adults (final N=38, ages 18–30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (2×3×2 ANOVA) and provides whole-brain results with thresholding and coordinates (Table 1; FWE-corrected clusters) and figures (e.g., Social > Non-social contrast). Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI social-task studies with healthy adult whole-brain results. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only groups, or non-empirical paper) apply.

The study uses task-based fMRI with a social stimulus (angry facial expressions) and explicit emotion regulation, meeting the social-related task requirement. The sample comprises healthy adult participants aged 18–57 (N=60; resting-state N=48), with demographics and neuropsychological screening reported, satisfying the healthy adult sample criterion. The paper reports multiple group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., Observe-angry > Observe-neutral; Observe-angry > Increase+Decrease) with tables of coordinates and figures, clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Whole-brain results are reported in tables and figures (and supplementary materials), which is acceptable. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study qualifies for inclusion.

This is an fMRI study that investigates prosocial learning (a social-related task) using task-based functional MRI and computational modeling. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=31, males aged 19–32). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task activation results (including FWE-SVC-corrected peaks and tables of coordinates) and presents whole-brain contrasts and conjunction analyses. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of mentalizing, empathy and prosocial behavior (social cognition/perception of others) in a healthy adult sample (N=32, females, mean age ~22.7). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Mentalizing > baseline; Dissimilar > Similar) with cluster-level correction and provides MNI coordinates/tables for activations. Behavioral and imaging results for the healthy control sample are reported separately and whole-brain results are clearly described in the text and tables. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults: 25 right-handed female participants (mean age 23.2) performed a social/mentalizing task about friends and kin during fMRI. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (friend > kin and parametric linear analyses across network layers), with cluster-thresholded statistical maps and tables of MNI coordinates and figures. These elements satisfy the review’s requirements for fMRI social tasks, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task activation reporting.

This is an fMRI study using a Face Matching Task (socially relevant processing of others' emotional facial expressions), conducted in a sample of healthy adults (n=10, mean age 25). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked contrasts and second-level one-sample t-test results (P<0.005 uncorrected) with coordinates and supplementary tables/figures. Therefore it meets the review objectives and all required inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social competition (social-related processing) in healthy adult participants (N=20 females, ages 18–35). The task explicitly manipulates social context (competition vs. no-competition) and probes social cognition/mentalizing. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Competition > No Competition at feedback) with tables of activation peaks and figures, and provides whole-brain analysis methods and corrected cluster thresholds. Healthy adult results are reported for the primary sample. Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria I3 (fMRI during social-related task), I4 (healthy adult sample 18–65), I5 (group-level whole-brain voxelwise task maps reported), and I6 (results presented in tables/figures and text). No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study that directly examines social-language processing and re-transmission, i.e., social communication/mentalizing, satisfying the review topic. Participants are healthy adult undergraduates (n=19; mean age 20.55), meeting the 18–65 age criterion. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked analyses (parametric modulators for ‘social language in’ and ‘social language out’) with thresholded whole-brain maps and tables of results (e.g., Tables 4 and 6, Figures 5 and 6), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented. The study is empirical fMRI work (not a review) and includes whole-brain results beyond ROI analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study uses task fMRI during a social-related face encoding/recognition paradigm (meets I3) and includes healthy adult participants (young subgroup aged 20–31; meets I4). However, the imaging analyses reported are region-of-interest (amygdala) extractions and parameter estimates; the paper does not report any group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps or whole-brain results for the healthy group. Because no unmasked whole-brain task effect for the healthy group is provided, the study fails inclusion criterion I5 and therefore must be excluded under exclusion criterion E2 (ROI-only analyses).

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition: participants performed an emotion-recognition task requiring integration of facial expression and eye-gaze (a clear social-related task). The sample includes a younger healthy adult group (reported as 17–27 years, mean ~20.65) and analyses are reported separately for the younger (healthy) group; the younger group contains participants within the 18–65 range and is analyzed/reported as a healthy adult group. Whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses were conducted (partial least squares whole-brain analyses) with results reported in figures and peak-coordinate tables for the healthy groups. Therefore the manuscript meets the fMRI social-task requirement and provides group-level whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps/results.

This study reports task-based fMRI during an empathy-for-pain paradigm (a social-cognitive task assessing perception and understanding of others’ pain), in a sample of healthy adult participants (male, age 18–40). The paper provides group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation results (whole-brain FWE-corrected analyses and peak MNI coordinates, conjunction analyses) clearly reported for the healthy participant groups (stress vs control). Behavioral and imaging results for the healthy groups are reported separately and whole-brain maps/coordinates are described in the text and supplementary material. Thus all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults are met.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (attribution of emotions to human and non-human faces) in healthy adults. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (age range 21–46) with group-level analyses reported. The paper reports whole-brain group-level task activation analyses (e.g., Emotion > Expression conjunctions, Face > Scramble contrasts) with cluster-level FWE correction and presents whole-brain maps and ROI results. Results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Therefore it satisfies the meta-analysis requirements for task-based fMRI of social cognition in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social perception (dynamic facial emotion and age judgments) in healthy adult participants (final n=25, ages 21–33). The study reports group-level whole-brain analyses (searchlight and random-effects whole-brain contrasts) identifying regions decoding task and stimulus valence; results are reported in figures and tables with corrected thresholds. Thus it meets the review’s requirements for an fMRI social-related task in healthy adults with whole-brain, group-level voxelwise results.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social interaction recognition (perception/understanding of others) using point-light displays, fulfilling the review’s social-related task requirement. The sample includes a separate healthy adult group (n=16, mean age 28.8) reported separately from children/adolescents. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task contrasts (SI > NM) with SPM8 analyses, peak- and cluster-level results, and coordinates/tables described in the text. Therefore it satisfies I3, I4, I5, and I6. No exclusion criteria (E2–E6) are triggered.

This study used task-based fMRI while healthy adult participants (ages 18–24) viewed news headlines/abstracts and made decisions related to sharing; the paradigm and analyses explicitly probe social-related constructs (self-related processing and mentalizing/social cognition). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (including thresholded whole-brain maps and tables, with permutation/FDR and cluster corrections) clearly identified for the healthy participant samples. Thus it meets criteria for fMRI social-related task, healthy adult sample, and provision of whole-brain task-evoked results.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants investigating person knowledge/social cognition. The paper reports task-based fMRI during social-related tasks (person memory/retrieval of biographical, status, and personality information) across two studies. Participants were healthy adults (study 1: n=24, Mage≈23; study 2: n=26, Mage≈20), within the 18–65 range. The manuscript reports group-level whole-brain task activation contrasts (e.g., all memory > baseline, status memory > baseline, trait memory > baseline; Fig. S3 and Table S6) and provides voxelwise coordinates and statistical maps/tables. Whole-brain results are clearly identified for the healthy/control groups. The study also includes MVPA, PPI, and DCM, but crucially provides univariate whole-brain task maps. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not only connectivity/resting-state, includes healthy adults, is empirical).

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (mentalising/theory of mind) in healthy adult participants (Experiments: N=39, ages 18–60; fMRI N=17, mean age 22), using task-based paradigms contrasting mentalising versus factual memory. The paper reports voxelwise, whole-brain second-level group analyses (SPM2), with thresholding and mapped results (figures and tables/coordinates) and describes group-level contrasts for the healthy participants (mentalising > factual; parametric modulation). Thus it meets all required inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI of social processing, healthy adult sample within 18–65, and whole-brain group-level voxelwise results (reported in text/tables/figures). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (ages 18–55) using an explicit social task (imitate/observe emotional faces) probing perception/understanding of others. The methods describe whole-brain preprocessing and group-level analyses (PLS and GLM) with voxelwise brain maps rendered in MNI space and thresholded voxel patterns reported, satisfying whole-brain task-evoked reporting. Healthy participant results are reported for the group (neuroimaging data from 20 participants used for final analysis). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults and provides whole-brain group-level task activation data.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (pseudo-interactive joke task assessing action-outcome contingency and self/other processing). Participants: 38 healthy adult volunteers aged 19–29 (within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (e.g., SELF vs OTHER; Group vs No Laughter; action-outcome contingency) with tables of coordinates and FWE-corrected cluster results. Whole-brain results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented in figures, tables, and text. Although additional PPI connectivity analyses are included, they do not replace the whole-brain task activation maps. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=41, ages 18–24). The task explicitly probes social-related processing (decisions about sharing with others, perspective-taking, and self/other relevance). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation results (select > content, share > content, share > select) with tables of coordinates and FWE-corrected clusters (see Table 2 and Figures), clearly attributed to the healthy participant group. Thus it meets the review’s requirements for task-based social processing, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social decision-making in groups. The neuroimaging cohort comprises healthy adult participants (ages 18–53), meeting the age/sample requirement. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task-evoked analyses (GLM, random-effects, voxelwise regressors, SnPM permutation correction) and lists activated regions with supplementary tables; unthresholded maps are shared on NeuroVault. Thus it provides healthy-group whole-brain task activation results for a social-related task. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range samples, or only between-group contrasts) apply.

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social decision-making paradigm (Trust Game) directly probing social reciprocity, satisfying the social-related task requirement. The sample comprises healthy adults aged 18–30 (n=19 included in imaging analyses). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (univariate analyses and cluster-corrected results) with tables of peak coordinates and cluster sizes (e.g., Table 3) and additionally reports ICA/network results; whole-brain results are clearly described. Therefore all relevant inclusion criteria are met (I3, I4, I5, I6) and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (participants aged 18–27) that uses a social cognition task (imagining personally familiar people across contexts). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain searchlight and ROI-corrected statistical maps and tables (cluster peaks and corrected p values), and presents whole-brain results in figures and tables. All required inclusion criteria for the review are met (I3, I4, I5, I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

This paper reports an fMRI experiment probing social-emotional processing (schadenfreude and fremdscham), i.e., perception/understanding of others and interpersonal emotions. Sample: N=34 healthy adult participants (males aged 19–31), satisfying the healthy adult sample requirement. The manuscript reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (SIT vs NEUT) with FWE-corrected results, tables of coordinates and figures, satisfying the whole-brain reporting criterion. Therefore it meets I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This is an fMRI study of theory-of-mind (social cognition) in healthy adults (N=22 after exclusions; mean age 24.4), meeting the review focus on social-related processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM results from an explicit general-belief localizer (false-belief vs false-photograph) with statistical threshold q(FDR)<0.05 and lists peak Talairach coordinates; results are shown in figures and described in the text. Thus it provides unmasked, healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked activation maps (reported as coordinates and images). All required inclusion criteria are satisfied (I3, I4, I5, I6). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only groups) apply.

This NeuroImage study used task-based fMRI to probe theory-of-mind/social cognition (mentalizing) using narratives and an explicit ToM localizer in healthy adult participants (ages within 18–65). The paper reports group-level localizer contrasts (Belief > Photo) used to define ROIs and references group maps/figures (SM and Fig. S1) and peak voxels, satisfying the requirement for a whole-brain task-evoked statistical map or reported coordinates. The sample consists of healthy adult groups (Exp.1 and Exp.2) with results reported for the healthy groups. The study therefore meets the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related task in healthy adults and provides whole-brain/statistical map evidence in figures/supplementary material. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state/seed-only, between-group-only, out-of-age-range, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (20 heterosexual men, ages 22–50) that used task-based fMRI presenting romantic, sexual, and neutral images to probe affiliation/attachment-related processing. The authors report whole-brain, voxelwise group-level analyses (FEAT/FLAME with cluster-wise correction) and present group and combined (all participants) task contrasts (e.g., sexual > neutral, romantic > neutral) in figures and tables of coordinates. These results constitute unmasked healthy-group task activation maps and are clearly described. The stimuli and contrasts target social/affiliative constructs (romantic love/pair-bonding), matching the review’s scope. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy or out-of-range samples, non-empirical) apply.

This study reports task-evoked fMRI in healthy adult participants during social/affiliation-related tasks (IAT about monogamy/adultery and go/no-go with attractive faces). Sample: 27 healthy right-handed males aged 20–32, meeting the adult healthy sample criterion. The paper reports group-level whole-brain contrasts for the IAT (incongruent vs. congruent) with cluster-level FWE correction and provides coordinates in Table 3, satisfying the requirement for a whole-brain task activation map. Results for the go/no-go task are also reported (right VLPFC activity), and whole-brain IAT results are clearly described. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This peer-reviewed fMRI study (healthy adult participants aged 20–32) explicitly investigates perception of social interactions using task-evoked fMRI contrasts (point-light and shape animations). It reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses and provides activation maps and coordinates (pSTS peaks) for the healthy sample. The experimental tasks probe social perception/understanding of others (helping vs. hindering), satisfying the social-related constructs. No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (60 healthy young adult men) that uses a social perception/evaluation task (impression-formation of faces varying in race and socioeconomic status). The paper reports both ROI analyses and group-level whole-brain second-level GLMs (exploratory whole-brain regressions) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster reporting (e.g., VMPFC cluster for status), satisfying the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task map. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (kinship/ moral dilemma) in healthy adults. It used whole-brain, task-based fMRI during an ecologically valid movie-viewing social/moral task and a separate moral-decision task. The sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=30, ages 19–39). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise results from inter-subject correlation (ISC) analyses and a GLM analysis of the moral-decision task, with multiple-comparison correction and tables/figures of clusters and coordinates (and unthresholded maps referenced). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This is an fMRI study of social-related perception (perception and understanding of others) in healthy adult participants (N=16, mean age 22.75). The task required judgments about point-light and human-like walkers’ facing direction, engaging social perception networks. Group-level, voxelwise task analyses were performed and reported (second-level contrasts, with stereotaxic coordinates and thresholded results provided), and results are described in the text/tables for the healthy sample. Although some analyses used masks for the Mirror Neuron and Mentalizing Systems, whole-brain second-level contrasts were obtained and coordinate-level whole-brain results are reported, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain evidence. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, non-empirical) apply.

The study is an fMRI task of social evaluation in healthy adult participants (meets I3 and I4). However, the manuscript reports group-level results that were small-volume corrected within a predefined vACC ROI and presents ROI-restricted activation clusters. There is no clear report of an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group. Because the paper appears to report only ROI-restricted analyses without accompanying whole-brain task-evoked results, it violates the review requirement for whole-brain evidence (E2).

Study meets I3 (fMRI of social/attachment processing using auditory attachment narratives) and I4 (healthy adult samples reported), but it does not report any task‑evoked, whole‑brain (voxelwise) activation maps from the listening task. The paper’s neuroimaging results are resting‑state, seed‑based functional connectivity contrasts (post‑narrative vs baseline) centered on caudate nucleus; these are connectivity/seed‑based resting‑state analyses rather than task‑evoked whole‑brain activation maps. This violates the requirement for a healthy‑group whole‑brain task activation effect (I5). Therefore the study should be excluded under E3.

The study is an fMRI experiment of collaborative vs. individual language/communication learning, addressing social communication and mentalizing (social-related processing). Participants are healthy adults (directors and matchers; ages reported 18–33). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts with cluster-corrected results and tables/figures listing coordinates; an ROI analysis is supplementary but whole-brain results are clearly presented. Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6, and no exclusion criteria (E2–E6) are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction processing in healthy adults. The task involved observing pictures of social interactions (cooperative vs affective) during BOLD-fMRI, satisfying the social-related task requirement. The sample comprises 36 healthy adults (ages within 18–65), satisfying participant inclusion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and cluster-corrected results (figures and Tables 1–3 provide voxelwise coordinates and cluster statistics), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement; results are clearly described in the text and tables (acceptable per I6). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only without task activations, and not a between-group-only or non-empirical paper). Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This is an empirical fMRI study of joint action with haptic contact — a social interaction paradigm examining leading, following, and mutual roles. The sample comprises healthy adult dancers (N=18, mean age 40.4) with no neurological/psychiatric history. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., partnered vs non-partnered, improvisation contrasts) with corrected thresholds and Talairach coordinates, presented in text/tables and figures. Thus it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI tasks in healthy adults and provides whole-brain results clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 21–48) that used an active task (viewing erotic pictures and videos of other people) engaging perception of others and reward-related/social-affiliative processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (within-group male vs female stimulus contrasts for each orientation group) with corrected thresholds (p<0.05 FWE) and cluster reports, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. The sample is healthy adults and results for the healthy groups are reported separately. Whole-brain results are presented in text, figures, and tables. No exclusion criterion (ROI-only, resting-state-only, age outside range, non-empirical) is violated. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 for the meta-analysis.

This study reports an fMRI task examining human perception of affective vocalisations (social communication/perception of others). It uses a healthy adult sample (N=19, mean age 25.9, within 18–65). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts are reported (species contrast human>chimpanzee>macaque) with coordinate tables and whole-brain statistical images (Table 2, Fig.2), satisfying whole-brain reporting (not ROI-only). The task is social-related (affective vocalization perception). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria.

This study uses task-based fMRI including a social cognition (Theory of Mind: TOM vs Random) task contrast in a large sample of healthy adults (n=787, ages 22–35+). Group-level, whole-brain task activation maps and Cohen's d/z maps are reported and visualized (figures, tables, and supplementary materials), with results explicitly described for the healthy cohort. The methods and results provide unmasked healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked maps suitable for meta-analysis of social processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, non-empirical) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-role judgment task (self, friend, celebrity) that probes social processing including Perception and Understanding of Self and Others. The sample comprises 37 healthy adult participants (mean age 22.9), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (self vs. celebrity; friend vs. celebrity) with statistical thresholds and tables of MNI coordinates (FDR-corrected), fulfilling whole-brain reporting requirements. Results are presented in tables and figures and described in the text. Although the study also includes PPI analyses, it additionally provides unmasked whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group, so all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction perception in healthy adults (ages 18–34). The tasks are social-related (perception/understanding of others) and functional MRI was used. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task contrasts (interaction > independent actions) with FDR-corrected clusters and whole-brain analyses described in the text and figures. Whole-brain results are clearly reported. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6, and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=20, ages 23–38) using a social decision-making task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) that probes perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation analyses (conjunction and contrasts such as COMP>COOP) with cluster-level multiple-comparison correction and tables/coordinates. Results for the healthy sample are clearly presented. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study reports task-based fMRI comparing social vs non-social images (a social-related valence appraisal task), uses healthy adult participants (N=14 included, ages 23–50), and presents group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (social > nonsocial contrast) with thresholding and conjunction analyses. Results include whole-brain statistical maps and ROI analyses derived from NeuroSynth; group-level task-evoked activation maps are clearly reported. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of emotion perception (social communication / perception of others) in healthy adult participants (ages 19–24 and 19.67±1.47), meeting the age and sample requirements. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (repeated-measures ANOVA; whole-brain PFWE<0.05; tables/figures of activations are provided), and whole-brain results are clearly described for the healthy/control group. Stimuli and tasks are social-related (facial and vocal emotion perception). Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria apply.

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social control-aversion task (social manipulation of another person controlling choices), meeting the social-related task requirement. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=51 after exclusions; mean age 22 ± 3), satisfying the age and healthy group criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (controlled > free) with cluster-level FWE correction and peak MNI coordinates, fulfilling whole-brain evidence reporting; results are clearly from the healthy/control group. Whole-brain results are presented in text, figures, and coordinates. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy, or non-empirical) apply.

The study reports a task-based fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=22, mean age 27.35) investigating social communication (recognition of communicative intentions from prosody). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (CLEAR > AMBIGUOUS and AMBIGUOUS > CLEAR) are reported with SPM8 and corrected thresholds, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps. Results are described in the text and figures/tables, and supplementary material is referenced. Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of self-related social processing (agentic and communal self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluations), in healthy adults (ages 19–24). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task contrasts and regression analyses with coordinates and cluster-level FWE-corrected results (tables and figures provided), clearly from the healthy sample. Thus it satisfies the review’s requirements for social-related task fMRI in healthy adults and reports whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked maps.

This is an fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adults (faces intelligence/friendliness), but the reported neuroimaging results were obtained via ROI-restricted analyses (“search regions were restricted to these ROIs”) and no unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked group map is reported. Thus it fails the requirement for whole-brain task activation reporting. Therefore it must be excluded under E2.

This is an fMRI study using a social-cognition task (modified Empathic Accuracy Task) that involves perception and understanding of others’ emotions. The sample comprises healthy adults (final fMRI sample N=34, ages 20–30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (random-effects paired t-tests, TFCE FWE-corrected results) with tables and figures of significant clusters. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult fMRI whole-brain task activations and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (three studies, combined N=59) performing social-related semantic tasks (person knowledge, socially relevant words), satisfying the review’s social-processing target. Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts are reported (e.g., social > non-social semantics) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster correction and peak coordinates presented, clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control participants; ROI analyses are supplementary. Study 2 includes control participants reported separately from patient data. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

The study reports task fMRI including a social cognition (theory-of-mind) task using healthy adult samples from HCP and UCLA, with voxel-wise GLM activation analyses and group-level whole-brain activation maps/figures (e.g., Figure 1 and Supplementary Figure S2) for the healthy/control group. Participants are healthy adults within the 18–65 range. Whole-brain results are reported in figures and supplementary materials, satisfying the meta-analysis requirements.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=55 males, mean age 24.9) using a social-related task (processing of erotic and fearful social scenes and faces). The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., erotic>neutral, fearful>neutral, erotic>fearful) with significance thresholds reported for whole-brain FWE-corrected results and ROI analyses; coordinates and figures/tables of whole-brain effects are provided. Thus it meets the review objective and satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state/connectivity-only, between-group-only, non-empirical, or age-out-of-range) are met.

This study acquired task-based fMRI during a mind-perception/social attention paradigm and reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses. Participants were healthy adults (N=22, mean age 24.36), within the 18–65 range. The paper describes whole-brain, cluster-corrected results (parametric analyses, conjunctions) identifying vmPFC and other regions and provides tables/figures of these group-level activation maps. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults and reports whole-brain healthy-group task effects.

This is an empirical fMRI study examining mothers (adult participants) processing their own child’s facial emotions — a clear social-related task (perception/understanding of others). The sample includes a healthy control group of adult mothers without lifetime mental disorder reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation results (e.g., own>unknown child contrast with FWE-corrected whole-brain results and within-group effects reported for the control group, e.g., medial frontal gyrus), satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Results are presented as ROI and whole-brain analyses and coordinates/statistics are reported. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

The paper reports a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (recall of formative relationship episodes involving self vs. others), addressing social cognition constructs such as self-/other-referencing and attachment. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=35, mean age 33.85) screened to exclude mental disorders. The authors report group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., self-relevant>control, other>control) with FDR cluster correction and provide tables/figures of significant clusters and coordinates. These whole-brain results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy group. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, participants are within age range, and it is an empirical fMRI study).

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It uses task-based fMRI during a social-related approach-avoidance task contrasting social vs nonsocial stimuli (relevant to social processing constructs); (2) Sample consists of healthy adults (male, mean age 21.35, N=76 analyzed) within the 18–65 range; (3) The paper reports group-level voxelwise analyses and describes exploratory whole-brain results beyond ROI analyses (with reference to whole-brain results reported in the manuscript/supplement); (4) Whole-brain results are acceptable to be in supplementary materials per criteria. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes healthy adult task activation maps). Therefore INCLUDE.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=16, ages 22–34) that used a social-related task (viewing and coding social interactions in a 20-min movie) and reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (FWE-corrected maps, cluster tables, ROI supplementary analyses, and coordinate tables/figures). Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria for task, sample, and whole-brain reporting (I3, I4, I5, I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (impression formation of faces varying by race and status) in healthy adult participants (N=60 males, mean age 23.8). The task is clearly social (impression formation), satisfying I3. The sample comprises healthy adults within 18–65, satisfying I4. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise multivariate PLS results (brain–behavior LVs) and displays/thresholds whole-brain voxel maps and cluster reports; GLM preprocessing and contrast images were used as input for PLS, providing group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps, satisfying I5 and I6. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state/seed-only, between-group-only, outside age range, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=24, mean age 26) examining neural integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions — a social-perception/communication task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts with FWE-corrected results and MNI coordinates (e.g., rpSTS) in the text/tables and figures. Independent localizers and whole-brain analyses are presented for the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for task relevance, sample, and whole-brain reporting.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (face-based trustworthiness judgments and feedback learning), satisfying the social-task requirement. It reports task-evoked, group-level voxelwise analyses and whole-brain ANOVA results (tables/figures and Supplementary Table 2), meeting whole-brain reporting standards. The sample includes a healthy younger adult group (ages 20–33) reported separately, satisfying the healthy adult (18–65) sample criterion despite also including older adults. Whole-brain results are clearly described in the text and tables. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of interactive joint-action (leading vs following) that probes social cognitive processes (mentalizing, perception of others) during a social task. Participants are healthy adults (n=18, mean ages ~40) within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Leading>Following, Following>Leading, conjunctions) with Talairach coordinates and figures, and whole-brain regression analyses; results are presented for the healthy participant group. Therefore it meets all listed inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults. The task explicitly required participants to infer and rate others' mental states (mentalizing), meeting the social-related task requirement. Participants were healthy adults (imaging N=28 after one exclusion; age range 18–22), satisfying the sample age criterion. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise results (searchlight RSA and voxelwise repetition-suppression analyses) with corrected statistical maps and peak MNI coordinates (e.g., dorsal mPFC, posterior precuneus), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results are presented at the group level for the healthy/control sample. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=20 males, ages 21–37) using a social decision-making task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) performed during functional MRI. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level task-evoked contrasts and flexible factorial/one-sample t tests with FWE cluster-corrected maps and tables of activations, clearly describing effects for the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain results.

This is an fMRI study using an interactive social task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) probing social interaction processing (meets I3). The sample consists of healthy adult participants aged 18–22 and analyses are reported for these healthy groups (meets I4). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (group-level GLM, whole-brain thresholding, cluster-corrected results, and Table 3/figures) examining responses to task outcomes and treatment-by-methylation interactions, i.e., group-level whole-brain maps from the healthy sample (meets I5). Whole-brain results are presented in text, tables and figures (meets I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

The study uses task-based fMRI of social perception (trustworthiness/fear appraisal) and includes a healthy adult control group; however, the paper does not clearly report a whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked statistical map explicitly identified for the healthy/control group alone. The reported whole-brain analyses appear to be across all participants or focus on group contrasts (BPD vs controls) and ROI analyses for the amygdala are reported for controls. Inclusion criterion I5 requires a clear, group-level whole-brain healthy/control task map; that requirement is not met. Therefore the study must be excluded under E4 (reporting only between-group contrasts or pooled analyses without an accompanying unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

This study reports an fMRI investigation of social provocation (modified Taylor Aggression Paradigm) in a sample of healthy adult males (age 18–35). It includes whole-brain, group-level task-evoked contrasts (high>low provocation and reversed contrasts) with family-wise error cluster-level correction and tables/figures of peak coordinates and clusters. The social task involves interaction with an ostensible opponent, meeting the social-related processing definition. Results for the healthy control sample are reported clearly and not restricted to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI hyperscanning study using a social interaction task (interactive pattern game) measuring interpersonal brain-behavior dependencies. Sample: 44 healthy adults (mean age 22.4), within 18–65. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (GLM, random-effects, FLAME) with non-parametric permutation correction (‘randomize’) and reports clusters/coordinates. Whole-brain results are clearly described. Therefore it satisfies the review criteria for inclusion.

The study uses fMRI during a social-related task (interpersonal pleasant touch) examining social reward processing, includes a healthy adult control group (matched non-using controls), and reports neural activation differences (within-group contrasts) indicating striatal responses to female vs male touch in controls. These constitute whole-brain, group-level task-evoked effects relevant to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, age outside range, or non-empirical) appear to apply.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social task (face-to-face conversation) and includes healthy control participants, it does not report any whole-brain, group-level task-evoked statistical map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The paper mainly reports (i) group comparisons (Autism vs Control) and task-driven connectivity analyses and (ii) task effects pooled across groups. Healthy-group-specific whole-brain task activation/connectedness maps are not presented. Therefore it fails the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task map and is excluded under E3 and E4.

The study investigates theory of mind (a social cognitive task: Perception and Understanding of Others) using task-based fMRI and resting-state data. It includes healthy younger adult participants (and older adults), so a healthy adult group within 18–65 is present. The paper refers to a task-defined theory-of-mind network, indicating group-level whole-brain task activation/contrast was used to define the network (consistent with reporting whole-brain task-evoked maps). Resting-state analyses supplement but do not replace task-based whole-brain results. Published in NeuroImage with task fMRI methods, meeting reporting standards. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults and reports whole-brain task results (or task-defined network) appropriate for inclusion.

The study investigates dynamic facial expression processing with fMRI and targets pSTS for neurofeedback (a social perception task), but the provided full-text information does not report a clear group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) healthy-group task activation map. The abstract and highlights describe a localizer and ROI/neurofeedback target selection across subjects but do not explicitly present whole-brain, voxelwise results for the healthy/control group; participant demographics and separate healthy-group maps are not clearly described. Therefore it fails the whole-brain evidence requirement (I5). Given the absence of whole-brain results, this study appears to report ROI-targeted analyses/neurofeedback without the necessary unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group activation maps and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (real-time mutual eye contact) in healthy adults. The task is explicitly social (mutual gaze/eye-blink entrainment) and uses functional MRI (hyperscanning fMRI) with task conditions (LIVE vs REPLAY). The sample is healthy adults (final analyzed N=30 participants; mean age ~21.7 years), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (LIVE > REPLAY) with cluster-level FWE correction and coordinates, and describes whole-brain interbrain synchronization and GLM results in the text/tables/figures. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of face perception/recognition (social perception of others) in healthy adult participants (mean ages ~23–25; all within 18–65). The study used task-evoked fMRI and reports group-level analyses (mixed-effects FLAME) and an independent group-level localizer (n=83) to define ROIs based on a faces > scrambled contrast, which constitutes a whole-brain group-level task map from healthy participants. Behavioral tasks are social-related (perception and recognition of faces). Whole-brain group analyses and results are described and used to derive group patterns; behavioral models are regressed against neural patterns. Therefore the paper meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related tasks in healthy adults and reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps. No exclusion criteria were triggered.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social interaction in healthy adults using an interactive conversational task (human–human vs human–robot). It reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., HHI vs HRI) with cluster-level FDR correction and provides neuroimaging maps (NeuroVault/OpenNeuro links). Sample comprises 21 healthy adult participants (mean age 25.8), within the 18–65 range. The paper includes whole-brain results presented in figures and described in the text. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=26, ages 18–27) that used a social cognition task (empathy for pain/pleasure toward human and robot agents). The paper reports group-level whole-brain random-effects analyses (main effects, interactions, cluster-corrected results) and provides whole-brain contrast maps and data (NeuroVault, OSF), meeting the requirement for task-evoked whole-brain healthy-group results. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social communication: participants (n=20 healthy native German adults, age range 22–35) watched naturalistic videos of an actor narrating a story with co-speech gestures (a social-communication task). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., low_ID > high_ID, speech > gestures+speech, gestures+speech > speech) with MNI coordinates and cluster statistics (tables and figures). Results are reported for the healthy participant group. Therefore it meets the review's requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and provides whole-brain task activation maps/coordinates.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a socioemotional Face Processing Task (fearful vs neutral faces) during functional MRI, addressing social-related processing (I3). The sample comprises 49 healthy adult participants (ages 18–33) with results reported for this healthy group (I4). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (F > N, N > F) using whole-brain TFCE/FWE-corrected analyses, including coordinates, figures, and descriptions in the text (I5, I6). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study used fMRI with a social task (Cyberball) and included a healthy adult control group, but it does not report an unmasked, whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group (e.g., HC within-group contrast such as inclusion>passive watching). The paper mainly reports between-group contrasts (BPD>HC, NSSI>HC) and conjunctions referencing HC; the HC within-group activation map is not presented in the manuscript (and HC main effects are not clearly reported here). Therefore it violates exclusion criterion E4 (reports only between-group contrasts without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect). Inclusion criteria I3 and I4 are met (fMRI social task; healthy adult group present), but I5 is not satisfied. Based on these points, the study should be excluded from the meta-analysis.

The study uses fMRI to investigate perception of animacy from visual motion cues, a social-related process (perception/understanding of others). It tested healthy adult participants (ages 19–36; N=111 total, with N=36 included in fMRI analyses after exclusions), meeting the sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task analyses (random-effects ANOVAs, conjunction contrasts, whole-brain FWE-corrected results, MNI coordinates and cluster tables/Figures), fulfilling the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group and include coordinates and figures (main text and supplementary tables). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical work) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for this review.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social task (cyberball) probing social exclusion/affiliation processes in healthy adult participants (female, mean age ~21.7). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses with voxelwise thresholds and coordinates (including clusters surviving FWE small-volume correction) and provides coordinate tables and described contrasts for the healthy/control sample. All required inclusion criteria for fMRI task activation in healthy adults are met, and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, or non-empirical) apply.

This paper reports task-based fMRI of multiple social cognition paradigms (false belief, animacy/intentional triangles, eyes intention, face trustworthiness, vocalizations) in a sample of 78 healthy adults (age 18–40). The authors present group-level, whole-brain random-effects (RFX) voxelwise analyses with corrected thresholds and provide peak coordinates and supplementary whole-brain results. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group task activation maps clearly. Therefore it satisfies the review's inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study (n=51 healthy adults, mean age 22.5) that investigates processing of dynamic facial expressions — a clearly social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (dynamic expressions > dynamic mosaics) with FWE-corrected statistical maps and detailed tables of coordinates. Results are reported for the healthy control sample and not limited to ROIs; whole-brain analyses and laterality comparisons are presented. Participants are within the 18–65 age range and healthy. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social perception (visual processing of dyadic interactions), using healthy adult participants (N=21, ages 18–35). The authors performed whole-brain preprocessing and GLM estimation to generate run-wise whole-brain beta maps and report group-level statistical analyses (one-sample t-tests) and whole-brain searchlight analyses. Results include group-level voxelwise classification/searchlight findings and discussion of whole-brain effects. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for: I3 (fMRI during social-related task), I4 (healthy adult sample 18–65), I5 (reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task analyses/maps), and I6 (whole-brain results clearly described). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only or resting-state-only) apply.

The study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=31, ages 18–35) using a social-perception task (gender judgments while viewing faces differing by facial disfigurement) that probes social-related processing (perception/understanding of others, stigma/dehumanization). The authors performed whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (SnPM nonparametric whole-brain contrasts, cluster-level FWE correction) and report significant whole-brain activations and deactivations for the healthy sample (figures/tables and ROI/item-wise follow-ups are provided). Thus the paper meets the fMRI social-processing objective, includes a healthy adult sample, and reports unmasked group-level whole-brain task activation maps. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study uses task-evoked fMRI of vocal emotional processing in healthy adults (ages 20–35), meeting social-processing and healthy-sample criteria. However, it does not report any group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps (or coordinate tables/figures of whole-brain activations). The paper presents ROI-based functional connectivity and graph-theoretical/network analyses using the Power-264 atlas rather than unmasked whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group. Therefore it fails inclusion criterion I5 and lacks acceptable whole-brain task results (I6 not met). Exclusion applies because results are ROI/network/connectivity-only without whole-brain task activation maps.

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social neuroeconomic task (prisoners' dilemma) probing social behaviour and cognition. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=15; ages 18–50) reported separately. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses for the control group (one-sample t-tests and per-group analyses with whole-brain results described and visualized; thresholding and cluster reporting are provided), satisfying the requirement for unmasked healthy-group whole-brain activation maps. Constructs assessed (trust/cooperation, mentalizing, face trustworthiness) fall within social-related processing. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state-only, or missing healthy-group whole-brain maps) apply. Therefore the study meets all relevant inclusion criteria for this review.

The study uses task-based fMRI of social processing (dynamic facial expressions) and includes a healthy adult control group, so I3 and I4 are satisfied. However, the paper does not report an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map clearly identified for the healthy/control group (TD). The reported whole-brain analyses focus on between-group comparisons and found no significant additional activations; the main task results are given as ROI/MANCOVA analyses and DCM (effective connectivity). Therefore it fails the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked map (I5) and thus meets exclusion criterion E4 (only between-group contrasts without an accompanying unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

This study uses task-based fMRI to examine social cognition (trust/honesty) during an advice-taking and trust-game paradigm, meeting the social-related task requirement. The sample consists of 31 healthy adult participants (mean age 24.3), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (voxel-level p<0.001 with cluster-level FWE correction p<0.05) and whole-brain MVPA/searchlight results, with coordinates and supplementary tables describing activations. Thus it provides whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps (reported in text, figures, and supplementary material). Based on these points, inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are satisfied.

This paper reports task-based functional MRI of action observation and weight-discrimination tasks probing perception/understanding of others (social perception). Healthy adult participants are included (multiple experiments with n=79 healthy participants; controls for the SCA6 patient study are reported separately), and group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation maps and contrasts (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS; Sleeve/NoSleeve) are reported and described in the text, figures, and supplementary materials. Whole-brain analyses and coordinates are provided, satisfying reporting requirements. The study is empirical fMRI work in healthy adults and does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, between-group-only contrasts, or non-empirical methods. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This study reports task-based functional MRI in healthy adult participants (Experiments 1 and 2; ages 18–41 and 18–33). The task contrasts vocal (socially relevant) versus non-vocal sounds and explicitly frames vocal processing as social communication/perception. Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise activation maps and contrasts (vocal > non-vocal and related analyses) are reported with statistical thresholds (FDR-corrected voxelwise maps and cluster thresholds). Whole-brain task-evoked results are clearly described for the healthy/control sample. Therefore the paper meets criteria for fMRI social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level reporting.

This study used task-based fMRI during observation of socio-affective (social touch) videos, directly addressing social-related processing (I3). The sample includes a clearly reported neurotypical healthy adult group (matched controls, ages within 18–65) with results presented separately from the ASD group (I4). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task activation results (univariate contrasts and accompanying figures/tables of activated brain areas and MNI coordinates for the control/NT group; see Additional file 1: Figure S2 and Table S2), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain voxelwise maps (I5). Reporting of whole-brain results in figures/tables meets the acceptability clause (I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study examining how collective (social) schemas influence memory, implicating social-cognition-related medial prefrontal regions (dmPFC/vmPFC). The task involved retrieval of museum images with emphasis on collective/social meaning, and analyses tested social/collective representations. The sample consisted of healthy adults (N=24; ages 22–39). The paper reports group-level whole-brain searchlight results (TFCE-corrected) and ROI analyses; whole-brain task-evoked maps and cluster results are clearly described. Therefore the study meets the review’s requirements for an fMRI social-related task in healthy adults with whole-brain group-level results.
